{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3327089,"name":"Angel Rodriguez","username":"Angel2950","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/angel2950/{size}/218665_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T19:41:33.030Z","cooked":"

I think anyone loves a robot with LEDs, I wanted to ask if there is a specific type that teams use so you can have awesome light effects without draining power. I have also heard teams using the lights as indicators.

looking for basic knowledge and resources. Thank you!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-03-07T19:41:45.910Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":143,"readers_count":142,"score":118.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":457756,"topic_slug":"robot-decorative-leds","display_username":"Angel Rodriguez","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64883,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team Captain"},"post_url":"/t/robot-decorative-leds/457756/1","custom_user_title":"Team Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3327111,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-07T20:02:24.249Z","cooked":"

There are some COTS solutions, but honestly, the simplest in my mind is to find any LEDs with WS2812B in the name, that means you don’t need a special controller and you can just control it with the Rio. The higher the LED density, the more LED you have total, and the brighter you have them set, the more power draw.

You get some kind of power regulator to get 12v down to 5v. We use this: Amazon.com
I think we can do about 1 meter of really dense (144 LEDs/meter) at max brightness white with this regulator without issue.

You plug one side of the regulator into the 12v lines of the PDB, and the other side into the LEDs. You split the 3 wires on the LED up so positive and negative go to the regulator, and negative and signal to the Rio on a PWM port.

Then finally, I’d get some defusers so that it looks better. Then do some programming to get them to indicate useful things, like having a note or not, target acquired, shooter revved up and ready, etc…

The Thrifty Bot has a link on their product page to some really good info. I have not used these, so I can’t comment on this product specifically. 12V Individually Addressable LEDs

You can get addressable or non-addressable LED lights. 12v or 5v light strips. Budget and programming skill might impact your decision. RevRobotics has and LED solution that requires minimal programming skills. Blinkin LED Driver - REV Robotics

There are options like always, no one right answer that satisfies all teams.
